Montgomery Dean, College of Uniuersity Honors THE PRESIDENT'S AWARD The President's Award at Middle Tennessee State University provides special recognition to individuals or organizations who have distinguished themselves through their exemplary service to MTSU; their extraordinary contributions to education, the community, or society; or their remarkable professional achievement. Asilver medallion, designed by Chris Brady and crafted by Klaus Kallenberger, with the phrase semper aspirare (always aspire) is presented as tangible evidence of this recognition. Today, Nobel laureate James M. Buchanan returns to his alma mater to become the third recipient of this award. MTSU proudly salutes this outstanding individual! 2 COMMENCEMENT SPEAKER Dr. James M. Buchanan, Nobel laureate Dr. James M. Buchanan, (B.S. '40), who grew up in rural middle Tennessee­the Gum community in Rutherford County. Despite his obvious brilliance and prodigious achievements, he seems never to have lost his independent spirit and the simple goodness of his roots. Buchanan the farm boy, the scholar, the man...ar.e still one and the same. He attended Buchanan School, so named because it was built on land once part of the Buchanan family farm. He came from a poor but distinguished family. His grandfather, John P. Buchanan, was elected governor of Tennessee in 1891. It was, however, his family's poverty, Dr. Buchanan has said, that provided him a strong family foundation and created a sense of determination, purpose, and frugality. Early on, it was determined that the young Buchanan would follow in his grandfather's steps and become a lawyer-politician. When the Great Depression put Vanderbilt University out of reach financially, he decided he could live at home, earn money for books and fees by milking cows, and attend the small college down the road. Dr. Buchanan studied at Middle Tennessee State Teachers College from 1936 to 1940. He graduated with majors in mathematics, English literature, and social, science. later that year, he was awarded a graduate fellowship in economics at UT­Knoxville and earned his master's degree in 194 I. He then won a fellowship in statistics at Columbia University for the 1941-42 academic year. However, military service intervened, and he was in the U.S. Navy by August 1941. After officer training and duty at Pearl Harbor and Guam, he was discharged in 1945. He went to the University of Chicago in 1946 and left with a Ph.D. degree in 1948. He received a Fulbright grant for the 1955-56 year and studied in Italy. In his book Better Than Plowing and Other Personal Essays (I 992, University of Chicago Press), he said of his undergraduate years, "Up until about my second year, I was not really sure about my own competence or ability. At the end of that year, however, the academic rankings were published, and, with all As that year, my name led all the rest. This result made me forget all about the first year C that Nooby Freeman had given me in mechanical drawing, the only C that I got during the whole of my academic career." cont. on next page 3 When Dr. Buchanan visited MTSU in 1997 to address the first Buchanan Scholars, he summed up his personal journey by sbaring words of advice. "I would emphasize the fact that students from Middle Tennessee can make it. In other words, they shouldn't stand in awe of the eastern establishment elite." "The mixed curriculum, bbth self-selected and imposed, served me well," Dr. Buchanan wrote of his college experience. "Economics, the discipline that was to become my scientific home, requires expository writing skills, logical structures of analysis, and a grounding in ultimate reality. And political economy, the branch of moral philosophy from which economics springs, requires philosophical coherence. I came away from Middle Tennessee with all of these... " In 1986, Dr. Buchanan was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences, of which he wrote, "If Jim Buchanan can get a Nobel Prize, anyone can. Recognition and acceptance of this simple truth are very importanL.Here was Jim Buchanan, a country boy from middle Tennessee, educated in rural public schools . and a local public teachers college, who is with an establishment university. who has never shared the academically fashionable soft left ideology, who has worked in totally unorthodox subject matter with very old-fashioned tools of analysis, chosen by a distinguished and respected Swedish committee." By describing Frank Knight. who was his mentor at the University of Chicago. Dr. Buchanan reveals who he is. "The qualities of mind that Knight exhibited were, and remain, those that I seek to emulate: the willingness to question anything. and anybody, on any subject anytime; the categorical refusal to accept anything as sacred; the genuine openness to all ideas; and finally, the basic conviction that most ideas peddled about are nonsense or worse when examined critically." Today, Dr. Buchanan, the author of several books and essays. serves as advisory general director of the Center for Study of Public Choice at George Mason University. in Fairfax, Virginia. Since 1911 Middle Tennessee State University has graduated 75,293 students since its incep­tion in I9 I I. These students have received associate, bachelor, masters, educational specialist. and doctoral degrees. Our first doctoral degrees were conferred on Decem­ber 22, 1972, and the first educational specialist degrees on December 20, 1974. There have been 31 Idoctoral degrees and 870 educational specialist degrees awarded since that time. 4
